posts.name:
Garett Moreau 🇺🇸
Garett Moreau 🇺🇸
posts.content:
Summary: threat actors are posing as "guides" offering legitimate software installation tutorials to lure viewers into reading the video descriptions or comments, where they then include links to fake software downloads that lead to malware.

The campaign appears to be similar to one that surfaced about a year ago spreading Lumma Stealer — a malware-as-a-service commonly used to steal sensitive information like passwords and cryptocurrency-wallet data.

Attackers continue to use social engineering tactics to target victims and apply a variety of methods to avoid security defenses, including: using large installer files, password-protected zip files, connections to legitimate websites, and creating copies of files and renaming them to appear benign.

comments.commentText: How much ransomware was there before cryptocurrencies came on the scene?..

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but it’s not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

It’s an internal step for:
– The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
– The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
– An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

It’s overlooked because:
– The SDR wants to hit quota.
– The sales manager wants to hit quota.
– Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if you’re serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isn’t the right fit.

Here’s why…

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that “ICP fray” was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as “nontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data sets”.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
– A scooter company managing location data.
– An HR team managing employee data.

They didn’t have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as “a slow death of a thousand cuts.”

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who don’t fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? ️ Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

posts.name:
Mark R. Koesterer
Mark R. Koesterer
posts.content:
Day 17 of The Rocky Steps Challenge: Unlocking Influence

The Power of Force Multiplication

Imagine throwing a rock into a body of water. Once the rock sinks beneath the surface, it’s gone—but the ripples it creates spread far and wide. This is the perfect analogy for a social media post: without the right strategy, your message sinks and disappears. But with force multiplication, you can turn those ripples into waves of influence.
The question is: How do you think you could maximize the impact of each post to amplify its reach and effectiveness?

I’m sharing leadership lessons with young athletes across the country, teaching them how to harness the power of force multiplication—leveraging every piece of digital communication to create lasting influence.

I'd like you to please follow me to learn how to turn your efforts into unstoppable ripples of success.

The wave is coming, let's start swimming together. Listen HERE:

posts.name:
Dr. Amit Shah, PhD
Dr. Amit Shah, PhD
posts.content:
𝐑𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐢𝐬𝐧’𝐭 𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞—𝐢𝐭’𝐬 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐥𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲

A truly reliable LLM isn’t just one that’s accurate most of the time. It’s one that behaves predictably and safely, even in edge cases or unfamiliar scenarios. But not all errors are equal—the severity of failure depends entirely on business context.

A creative AI generating a mildly offbeat response? 𝐋𝐨𝐰 𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐤.
An AI system in finance or healthcare misinterpreting data? 𝐏𝐨𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐩𝐡𝐢𝐜.

To ensure true reliability, we need a structured, multidisciplinary approach that evaluates AI within the right business context. This means:
️ Defining operational constraints based on risk tolerance and business impact.
️ Quantifying and mitigating errors with a risk-severity framework.
️ Establishing clear boundaries to prevent high-severity failures.

This boundary-driven approach ties back to my Ph.D. research in neuromotor control, where stability and predictability were essential in modeling movement. Biological systems self-regulate within constraints to prevent failure—AI systems must do the same.

This is why I take a multidisciplinary approach—pulling from risk management, control theory, and real-world business applications—to design safeguards that prevent AI from operating outside safe limits. Businesses adopting AI can’t afford to treat reliability as an afterthought. It has to be built into the system from the start.

 How does your industry approach AI failures? Do you see structured safeguards in place, or is it still mostly reactive? Let’s discuss.

posts.name:
Mando Sallavanti III, CFP®, CEPA
Mando Sallavanti III, CFP®, CEPA
posts.content:
"I'll never be a doctor like my father."

Those words crushed me in my sophomore year of college.

My entire identity was built around following his path:

→ Everyone called me Doc
→ It was my dream since childhood
→ My father was my first hero

But life had different plans.

That's when my dad introduced me to.

And everything changed.

Timmy didn't just show me what being a financial advisor looked like. He showed me what it meant to truly impact lives.

The start wasn't pretty:

→ 8 months of constant rejection
→ Zero confidence in client meetings
→ Struggling to find my next prospect

But Timmy stood by me.

He saw something in me that I couldn't see in myself.

Fast forward to today:

→ 60 clients on retainer
→ A waitlist of prospects
→ Leading our firm in Financial Planning for 2024

When Timmy presented me this award (video below), I fought back tears.

Because sometimes the best path isn't the one you planned.

It's the one God puts in front of you.
And He sends the right people to guide you there.

Watch Timmy's speech below.

It's a reminder that mentorship isn't just about business.

It's about believing in someone until they can believe in themselves.

comments.commentText: You are a Dr. of Finance.

posts.name:
Himanshu Singh
Himanshu Singh
posts.content:
"Why UPSC?"—The Most Overused Yet Tricky Question!

If I had a rupee for every time a mock interview panel asked me this question, I’d have enough to retire and not need UPSC at all.

Picture this: You walk into the interview room, nerves intact, dreams in place, and the panel drops the question—“Why do you want to leave your high-paying job for UPSC?” Cue awkward silence and your brain playing the Jeopardy theme.

At first, I thought I nailed it:
"To contribute to society!" – Too vague.
"Dreaming of public service since childhood!" – Too cheesy.
"To make a real difference!" – Too predictable.

Spoiler alert: None of it worked. The panelists still looked at me like I was trading a Lamborghini for a bicycle.

Enter my friend, who clearly had enough of my existential crisis. He said, “Bro, go watch Aditya Shrivastava’s interview—AIR 1, UPSC 2023. The man left a 50 LPA Goldman Sachs job and owned that question.”

So I did. And let me tell you—his answer was a masterclass in simplicity and logic. He basically said, “It’s not about what I’m leaving behind; it’s about what I’m stepping into. The private sector builds, but the civil services shape. That’s the kind of impact I want.”

Boom. Mic drop. Interview cracked.

Now, as I sit here trying to carve out my own “magic bullet” answer, I thought, why not turn to my LinkedIn fam?

What would YOU say if someone asked you this question? Why choose UPSC over unicorn startups, FAANG jobs, or even high packages?

For me, it’s the chance to:

Work on transformative issues like poverty, education, and infrastructure.

Help craft policies that impact millions.

Maintain international relations that define our global presence.

And yes, to be part of something bigger than myself.


But enough about me—your turn! Drop your wittiest, smartest, or most heartfelt answer in the comments. Bonus points if it’s funny (I need all the help I can get before my next mock).

Let’s crack this question together—one clever answer at a time. Who knows, your perspective might just help me land that IAS tag someday!

comments.commentText:
1. Multidimensional Impact:A high-paying job affects one's life, but a civil servant’s decisions impact millions. Civil services offer roles in governance, policymaking, and global relations, with new challenges every day.

2. Variety of Work:Unlike the repetitive private sector or other government departments like SSC CGL and PSUs, civil services offer dynamic work. One day it’s fieldwork; the next, policy-making or managing systems. There’s never a dull moment.

3. Inspired by the System:Many issues arise from gaps in governance. UPSC offers a chance to bring change, and sometimes we also think that if we were there, we could do it in a better way.

4. A Platform for Change:Being an IAS officer means influencing policies and solving problems—bigger than personal ambition. You have the power to save the law, help the people of the nation, and execute things in a better way, having the authority to make them the best.

5. Mixed Motivations for Becoming an IAS:
Not everyone joins the IAS to serve the nation. Some seek power, respect, and the main thing is corruption. In North India, IAS is pursued for prestige and societal pressure to become a 'collector,' with some motivated by power or corruption. (5th point is my thinking)
